prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B9 continuum IRAS13349+2438
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We will observe the central point-like source in several Type 1 and Type 2 AGNs at the highest spatial frequecy available, in order to partially resolve the radial structure of the brightness distribution.
Since sources are spread over the sky with each separation more than 10 degrees, a separate Science Goal has to be made for each source.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our goal is to observe each source at the highest spatial frequency available in order to at least partially resolve the structure of the central point-like source. Thus we require Band 9 with the most extended configuration. We plan to do a primitive analysis of looking at visibilities and phases directly, and try to detect a decrease of visibilities as a function of baseline length (Fig.3).
Each source is estimated to have approximately 50 mJy at 680GHz (extrapolated from slightly shorter wavelength observations). With the minimum on-source time of 2 minutes, we can achieve ~2 mJy sensitivity. However, just in case of a little over-estimate (up to a factor of a few) of the point-source flux, we would like to achieve 1 mJy sensitivity, which only adds several minutes to the total execution time per target. This will be sufficient to implement the visibility analysis as a function of spatial frequencies. Snapshot uv coverage will also be sufficient for the visibility analysis.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The AGN obscuring torus, the key structure in the AGN mass accretion process as well as in the unification scheme, is finally being spatially resolved with the very high angular resolution capability given by long-baseline interferometers in the infrared. Based on the results for a sizable sample of objects, a unifying view of the material distribution on a few tens of milli-arcsec scale (or sub-pc) is now emerging. Here we propose to test robust, important predictions that are coming out from this unifying view, using the highest spatial resolution currently available at sub-mm wavelengths. The tests, if confirmed, would further shape a comprehensive picture of the accretion-ejection processes in the nuclear region. In particular, we will explore evidence for the radiation pressure effect at high accretion rates, leading to a quantification of the AGN accretion-ejection processes and feekback effect at large.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Niels Bohr Institute, Copenhagen, University of
Department of Physics, California at Santa Barbara, University of
Division of Astronomical Sciences, National Science Foundation
Institute of Theoretical Physics and Astrophysics, Kiel University
